qas.question: How does the lifecycle of most insects typically begin?
What is the primary constraint on the physical growth of an insect?
What stage of development differentiates a 4-stage metamorphosis from a 3-stage metamorphosis, notably absent in the latter?
What is the term given to denote the series of stages involved in the development of an adult insect?
What era is attributed to the findings of enormous fossilized dragonflies with extremely long wingspans?
Insects growth is constrained by what?
An insects developement involves a series of what?
How many stages of metamorphosis does an insect go through?
The most diverse insects coevolved with what?

context: The life cycles of insects vary but most <a0_0>hatch from <a5_0>eggs<a5_0/><a0_0/>. Insect growth is constrained by <a6_0>the <a1_0>inelastic exoskeleton<a6_0/><a1_0/> and development involves a series of <a7_0>molts<a7_0/>. The immature stages can differ from the adults in structure, habit and habitat, and can include a passive pupal stage in those groups that undergo <a8_0>4-stage<a8_0/> metamorphosis (see holometabolism). Insects that undergo 3-stage metamorphosis lack a <a2_0>pupal stage<a2_0/> and adults develop through a series of <a3_0>nymphal<a3_0/> stages. The higher level relationship of the Hexapoda is unclear. Fossilized insects of enormous size have been found from the <a4_0>Paleozoic<a4_0/> Era, including giant dragonflies with wingspans of 55 to 70 cm (22–28 in). The most diverse insect groups appear to have coevolved with <a9_0>flowering plants<a9_0/>.
